remarks: Lemma for ~ acexmid .  Here we divide the proof into cases (based on the disjunction implicit in an unordered pair, not the sort of case elimination which relies on excluded middle). The cases are (1) the choice function evaluated at ` A ` equals ` { (/) } ` , (2) the choice function evaluated at ` B ` equals ` (/) ` , and (3) the choice function evaluated at ` A ` equals ` (/) ` and the choice function evaluated at ` B ` equals ` { (/) } ` . Because of the way we represent the choice function ` y ` , the choice function evaluated at ` A ` is ` ( iota_ v e. A E. u e. y ( A e. u /\ v e. u ) ) ` and the choice function evaluated at ` B ` is ` ( iota_ v e. B E. u e. y ( B e. u /\ v e. u ) ) ` .  Other than the difference in notation these work just as ` ( y `` A ) ` and ` ( y `` B ) ` would if ` y ` were a function as defined by ~ df-fun . Although it isn't exactly about the division into cases, it is also convenient for this lemma to also include the step that if the choice function evaluated at ` A ` equals ` { (/) } ` , then ` { (/) } e. A ` and likewise for ` B ` . (Contributed by Jim Kingdon, 7-Aug-2019.)
statement:
acexmidlem.a $e |- A = { x e. { (/) , { (/) } } | ( x = (/) \/ ph ) } $.
acexmidlem.b $e |- B = { x e. { (/) , { (/) } } | ( x = { (/) } \/ ph ) } $.
acexmidlem.c $e |- C = { A , B } $.
acexmidlemcase $p |- ( A. z e. C E! v e. z E. u e. y ( z e. u /\ v e. u ) -> ( { (/) } e. A \/ (/) e. B \/ ( ( iota_ v e. A E. u e. y ( A e. u /\ v e. u ) ) = (/) /\ ( iota_ v e. B E. u e. y ( B e. u /\ v e. u ) ) = { (/) } ) ) ) $.
$d A u v x y z $.
$d B u v x y z $.
$d C u v x y z $.
$d ph u v x y z $.
